description:
Penicillium crustosum is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Penicillium. It is a common saprophytic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter, and can be found in various environments, including soil, food, and indoor settings.

Penicillium crustosum is known for its ability to produce secondary metabolites, including a range of mycotoxins, which are toxic compounds that can have harmful effects on humans and other organisms. These mycotoxins include patulin, roquefortine C, and cyclochlorotine, among others.

The fungus has a characteristic green-blue or blue-green appearance, with a velvety or powdery texture, and can form colonies that appear as small, round, or irregular patches on the substrate. Microscopically, Penicillium crustosum produces branched conidiophores (spore-bearing structures) with brush-like arrangements of phialides (specialized cells that produce conidia, or asexual spores).

Penicillium crustosum is commonly encountered in food products, such as cheese, bread, and other baked goods, where it can cause spoilage and contamination. Its presence in food can be a concern due to the potential production of harmful mycotoxins, which can pose a risk to food safety and human health.
